description.narrative: Zambian institutions have adequate capacity and policies to ensure inclusive, transparent, accountable and integrity-based democratic processes.

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

comment.narrative: Desk review of ECZ, ZNWL, and Election Observation Reports ECZ statistics Desk review of ECZ Reports and CSO Reports Monitoring of CSO work plan and reports ZAPD Reports Monitoring of ZCID work plans and deliveries Desk review of ZCID Reports Desk review of Ministry of Justice Reports

1.1. Support for inclusive participation 1.1.1 Support to women and youth participation in elections
The project has shortlisted consultants to provide Technical Assistance to develop and implement strategies/outreach activities to increase women & youth participation in elections. The consultancy will to provide technical assistance to assess existing policy frameworks and strategies to promote effective and meaningful participation of women and youth in elections, either as voters, candidates and/or election officials.
The consultant is expected to produce a comprehensive report that assesses the situation regarding the participation of women and youth in the electoral process and recommend strategies to increase the participation of women and youth in elections and overall public decision-making processes. From the recommendations the project will develop products and implement activities designed to enhance inclusion of the women and the Youth. The recruitment process of the consultant is expected to be completed and commence work within the first quarter of 2021.
Further, UNDP has developed the sub-granting guidelines and subsidiary documents for small grants awards to deserving civil society organizations to implement activities designed to increase participation of women and youth in elections. The grants will have a ceiling of up to $50, 000 per applicant and they will be expected to have been in operation for at least 3 years among other requirements. The call for application for these grants is being processed and is planned for issue by 1st Quarter 2021.
1.1.2: Participation for Persons with Disabilities (PWDs) in elections increased The UNDP’s ongoing support to strengthen Zambia’s efforts to achieve a transparent and inclusive democratic system include programming and activities designed to address barriers to effective participation by special groups such as PWDs. In this regard, UNDP has commenced the recruit of a consultant to provide technical assistance (TA) to review existing procedures/strategies/ publications targeting PWDs for meaningful participation in elections as voters and as candidates in the context of the 2021 electoral cycle and beyond.
The consultant is to review the relevant electoral processes, procedures, legal and policy frameworks and targeted measures within public institutions such as the ECZ and the National Assembly, Civil Society organizations and political parties to identify barriers that hinder the meaningful participation of PWDs and recommend strategies to increase their inclusivity and outreach to promote their inclusive participation.
The recruitment process of the consultant has advanced to the evaluation stage and like the Women and youth consultancy referred above is expected to commence in the first quarter of 2021. As the outcome of this process the project will develop up to seven (7) products to enhance the participation of the PWDs in the electoral process at all levels leading to the 2021 general elections.
1.1.3: Electoral participation of Persons in Lawful Custody (PLC) enhanced In the month of October, UNDP supported the Electoral Commission of Zambia and the Zambia Law Development Commission to hold Four (4) Stakeholder Consultative Meeting on the Operationalization of the Right to Vote by Persons in Lawful Custody at Mulungushi Conference. The four (4) consultative meetings were held with four different categories of stakeholders namely: Civil Society/Political parties, Law Association of Zambia, Judiciary and the Défense and Security Wings. The stakeholders were categorized in this manner to get the most out of the respective stakeholders.
The purpose of the stakeholders meetings were to share the contents of the preliminary report and draft Bills developed by ZLDC working in collaboration with ECZ and the Technical Committee Electoral participation of Persons in Lawful Custody (TC) following the mapping exercise, virtual comparative studies, and the legislative audit, and the drafting exercise. The meetings also sought to solicit for input, observations, and recommendations from the stakeholders on the outputs of the processes conducted by ZLDC and the TC.

Output 1.1.: Support for inclusive participation 1.1.1 Proportion of eligible voters who are registered to vote, disaggregated by sex, age, and excluded groups; (Note-Data on rural/urban disaggregation not available) a. 1.1.1 two (2) knowledge products on women participation in the electoral process developed. 1.1.2 200 copies of Knowledge products on women participation printed and disseminated. 1.1.3 National Conference on PLC voting held, and report disseminated
1.2.1 At least 10 outreach activities by women MPs to promote women’s participation in elections and politics. 1.2.2 40% increase in knowledge among participants. 1.2.3 At least 3,500 women reached by Women MPs Outreach activities. 1.2.4 At least 15% increase in participation of women through parliamentary debates based on the review of Hansard records 1.2.5 30% of MPs have an active online account to interact with their constituents
1.3.1 At least 10 DEMOG sign up to the Charter.
2.1.1 At least 2 capacity building training sessions for Committee members and staff, held in 2021. 2.1.2 40% increase in knowledge among participants.
2.2.1 At least 3 gender-sensitive knowledge products developed for each level of elections (Presidential, Parliamentary and Local government) 2.2.2 Four (4) trainings- At least one training session conducted for each category: i.e., judges, magistrates, prosecutors, and private counsel with at least 40% female representation. 2.2.3 Forty per cent (40%) change training in knowledge among beneficiaries.
3.1.1 National call center established and operational. 3.1.2 At least 15 media houses accredited to the media corps with equitable representation of women. 3.1.3 200 copies of the Gender Policy printed and disseminated 3.2.1 NA communication strategy launched (200 copies of the NA communication strategy printed and disseminated) 3.2.2 Online platform for citizens engagement developed and rolled out 3.2.3 At least 3 (1 each quarter) dialogue session held in 2022 between the National Assembly, the media, and the public on National Assembly mandate. 3.2.4 At least 60% of MPs hold 1 online engagement per quarter with the citizens with a focus on female MPs 3.3.1 60% of registered media houses accredited to the iVerify Zambia mechanisms disaggregated by type (print, radio, TV) 3.3.2 two (2) gender sensitive knowledge products on election related disinformation, misinformation and hate speech
4.1.1 ECZ institutional assessment undertaken, and capacity building rolled out during 2022 4.1.2 Voter turnout survey conducted 4.1.3 voter education in the Zambian School Curriculum developed
